name.text: 37.2.2 Expectation and variance of the binomial distribution

questiontext.text:
Expectation and variance of the binomial distribution

For a binomial distribution \(X\sim B(n,p)\), the mean and variance, as we shall see, have a simple form. While we will not prove the formulae in general terms - the algebra can be rather tedious - we will illustrate the results for cases involving small values of \(n\).

The case \(\pmb n\pmb =\pmb 2\)

Essentially, we have a random variable \(X\) which follows a binomial distribution \(X\sim B(2,p)\) so that the values taken by \(X\) (and \(X^2\) - needed to calculate the variance) are shown in the following table:


\(x\) \(x^2\) \(\text{P} (X=x)\) \(x\) \(\text{P} (X=x)\) \(x^2\) \(\text{P} (X=x)\)
0 0 \(q^2\) 0 0
1 1 \(2qp\) \(2qp\) \(2qp\)
2 4 \(p^2\) \(2p^2\) \(4p^2\)


We can now calculate the mean of this distribution: 

\(\text{E}(X) =\sum x\text{P} (X=x)=0+2qp+2p^2=2p(q+p)=2p\qquad \text{since}\ q+p=1\) 

Similarly, the variance \(V(X)\) is given by 

\( V(X) =\text{E}(X^2)-[\text{E}(X)]^2=0+2qp+4p^2-(2p)^2=2qp\)


Example

Calculate the mean and variance of a random variable \(X\) which follows a binomial distribution \(X\sim B(3,p)\).

Solution

The table of values appropriate to this case is:

\(x\) \(x^2\) \(\text{P} (X=x)\) \(x\text{P} (X=x)\) \(x^2\text{P} (X=x)\)
\(0\)\(0\)\(q^3\)\(0\)\(0\)
\(1\)\(1\)\(3q^2p\)\(3q^2p\)\(3q^2p\)
\(2\)\(4\)\(3qp^2\)\(6qp^2\)\(12qp^2\)
\(3\)\(9\)\(p^3\)\(3p^3\)\(9p^3\)

Hence \(\quad \text{E}(X)=\sum x\text{P} (X=x)=0+3q^2p+6qp^2+3p^3=3p(q+p)^2=3p\qquad\text{since } q+p=1\)

\[\begin{aligned} V(X)&=\text{E}(X^2)-[\text{E}(X)]^2\\ &=0+3q^2p+12qp^2+9p^3-(3p)^2\\ &=3p(q^2+4qp+3p^2-3p)\\&=3p((1-p)^2+4(1-p)p+3p^2-3p) \\ &=3p(1-2p+p^2+4p-4p^2+3p^2-3p)=3p(1-p)=3pq\end{aligned}\]

From the results given above, it is reasonable to asert the following result in the Key Point below


Key Point

Expectation and Variance of the Binomial Distribution

If a random variable \(X\) which can assume the values \(0,1,2,3,\dots , n\) follows a binomial distribution \(X\sim B(n,p)\) so that

\(\text{P} (X=r)= \ ^n C_rp^rq^{n-r}= \ ^n C_rp^r(1-p)^{n-r}\)

then the expectation and variance of the distribution are given by the formulae

\(\text{E}(X)=np\qquad \text{and}\qquad V(X)=np(1-p)=npq\)
